job_title: Registered Nurse in South Miami, FL
pros: It is possible to learn a lot. A lot of nurses and doctors are very knowledgable and able to teach you a lot. They do interdisciplinary rounds and make the nurse at the heart of the round as they have to give a full report about the patient. The stepdown is a real and lively unit in which only people with critical care are there. Once the patient is stable, they go on another floor.
cons: They make patients move all the time; sometimes they leave to a more stable unit, but one day later go back to critical unit, so perhaps they could try to handle that better that patients do not move so much; in addition it is tremendous work for the nurse and the other personel. The stepdown floor is small so the staff could get really close, but it is very hard to get accepted in this small where a lot of people are friends and, for some of them, they do not accept new people and do not make them feel at ease.

review_title: High turnover rate, employees overworked so they leave. Some employees were pleasant to work with.
pros: Some employees were pleasant to work with.
cons: High turnover rate, employees overworked and so they leave. This is because when people leave, instead of having a replacement, they distribute that work amongst the rest of the other people within the team who already have their own high volume of work, making them do the work of 3 or more people. This adds to calling out sick/ use your PTO hrs. to rest and regain your energy at home because the high stress/ high pressure they put on you gets you sick. So there is a breaking point where the employees can't take it anymore and are forced to quit or get fired due to upper management not doing anything about this issue, since apparently they prefer to overwork their employees instead of hiring more employees to balance the high volume workload/ stress. People leave after only working there for 6 months or less after realizing they are getting overworked with more work being piled on top of them.

review_title: Great opportunities, good pay and environment
pros: There are many opportunities to grow at Baptist. The work environment is great, the nurses are great and support each other, at least on the floor that I've worked on. The great majority of employees are professional towards each other and towards the patients. The pay is good compared to other hospitals. The nurse-to-patient ratio is comparable to other hospitals (6 patients for med/surg tele nurse), but a lot of times you may start the shift with less patients (4-5). Even though it is sometimes too stressful (as it is for any med/surg position)there are ways that Baptist tries to help. Sometimes there will be a runner on the floor to assist, and the charge nurse helps out a lot.
cons: Just like any other med/surg floor, it is stressful.

pros: Overall culture , location, benefits, childcare and the aesthetics of the building are very nice .
cons: As a social worker for baptist hospital of miami the demands are unrealistically high. The workload has always been challenging due to the fact we deal with people at the lowest point in their lives,  however, lately its sky rocketed with the decrease in staff.  The social workers with the most experience are slowly dwindling because of the lack of basic work life balance.   Leadership is only interested in hiring social workers right out of school for the lowest salaries possible.  As the number of social workers decrease the number of supervisors increase..... it makes you wonder .... who are the supervising?   Social workers are expected to work unrealistic hours and have a very difficult time taking time off.  Leadership is in a cloud of their own as they never cover floors and have no clue what their staff is actually doing on a daily basis.  Furthermore they are  not in touch with the low morale of their staff.. Health care as a whole is changing and the CEOs are more interested in the bottom line and “budget” rather than the actual quality of care given to their patients.

job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Miami, FL
pros: Baptist is a great place to work. The culture is very compassionate and co workers are very caring. However the opportunity for advancement is lacking. In addition, senior leaders to do not clearly articulate vision and strategy. It is a very change averse environment which tends to drive out forward thinking people. Also, the human resources function in particular needs to be streamlined to be more efficient and innovative to keep up with industry changes, best practices and newer he service delivery models. Progress is slow as there is a lot of resistance, in addition to some entitlement and "that's not my job" attitude. Overall, this place is a good start for your career if you're looking for steady, stable employment, a caring and compassionate organizational culture and brand name recognition that is highly respected across South Florida. However, do not expect for innovative, forward-thinking change or career advancement.
cons: Lack of career advancement, lack of innovation and forward thinking in HR, change resistance, lack of succession planning, lacking of HiPo identification, engagement and retention.

review_title: Not the best place to be your best anymore
pros: The best thing about this organization is the health benefits it provides. Although yearly deductibles and visit copays have gone up in the last couple of years, they are still lower than most other local healthcare systems.
cons: Salary ranges overall are low, haven't been competitive for some time now. Yearly merit increases are pitiful. Bonuses are down almost 30% as compared to last year. absolutely zero growth and promotional opportunities. Majority of the organization is plagued by nepotism.

pros: Great place to work and grow as a nurse. The staff and managers are all very friendly, helpful, and this makes the working environment easier. I was a float nurse and it seemed to be this way on most floors. The busier floors, even though they were stressful, it was easier getting through the day just because of how helpful everyone else is. You get the charge nurse, the other floor nurses, patient care techs, Respiratory therapists, occupational therapists, physical therapists, the manager for the floor, and even the doctors are all available and ready to help you out with your patients.
cons: Last year when I worked here, I knew it was the lowest paying hospital to RNs, and also, like any hospital, it could get really busy and stressful to work a lot of the year. Also, as far as easy scheduling for work/can't work days, it all depends which manager for which floor you are working on.

review_title: MCI RADIATION- Awful management/ very disorganized and incompetent/ love to fire people
pros: My team of radiation therapists were great to work with.
cons: Everything else apart from my team was the worst experience I have had working in a large cancer center.  I decided to resign due to the incompetence of my direct supervisors.  Many good employees have been fired since the opening of Miami Cancer Institute.  MCI does not value its employees; you are only a number.  This is the same attitude they have with their patients.  Everything is rushed and disorganized.  Mistakes are bound to happen when you have this type of management.

pros:
The hospitals are not-for-profit and employees receive annual bonuses.
The employees who work for the hospitals are generally happy and get along well.
Senior management leaders acknowledge your concerns.
When rounding on patients other healthcare professionals including physicians welcome and respect your input for the care of your patients.
The laundry list of benefits and employee programs (carpool services, onsite-child care services, in the home elderly-care services, available emergency funds, assistance with home purchaces......)
cons:
The workload is heavy. You can easily go through 8 to 9hrs in a 12hr work day without resting if you work in nursing, respiratory therapy, and other clinicians that deal with patient care.
The pay is not the lowest but it is not competitive either.  
Some departments/units/floors have great supervisors and directors while others do not. A change in department can easily change your impression of your workplace.

pros: The pros are the benefits.  But that is going south now too.
cons: There is a lot of favoritism.  Management will let the lazy people get away with being non productive and work the High Performers to death.  They chase away all the people with good work ethic or work them until they get hurt and then they stay out on FMLA forever putting more pressure on the team.  Baptist used to be a great place to work until this transformation 20/20 stuff.  Now you can't even waste a sheet of toilet paper without someone threatening your job.  It is becoming too stressful to even come to work every day.

pros: Baptist is trying to remain afloat and beat the competition cutting costs in all corners while trying to maintain cutting edge technology and high skilled staff.
cons: Transformation 20/20 - the cutting cost process actually - has decreased the employees morale tremendously. They recently had a voluntary opportunity to "quit" your job by offering laughable incentives for the ones willing to do it. They are cutting benefits from the employees who earn the least like movie tickets which were delivered on the day of our birthdays. In the meantime big salaries are still being paid to the upper management with no signs of cuts anywhere.

pros: Good benefits, good perks, established company that contributes to the community, open access to executive leadership with good transparency comparitively

cons: nurse patient ratio is ridiculous.........Im lucky if i get to pee before 2pm and forget about eating or sitting down in a 12 hour period.  It is not fair to my patients to have a nurse that can not give them the medical and emotional support they need and deserve.

review_title: Very corporate America! Use to be such a great organization, not anymore.
pros:
Great benefits, brand name, great clinical staff, great co-workers, job security, prestigious institute, great work-life balance (I'm sure it depends on the dept you work for), they care about employees time off, they most definitely care about their patients. 
Some of my previous leaders have REALLY cared about their employees and really listen to their needs. 
Has grown so much as an organization
cons:
Some of leadership is terrible! To the point that  you wonder how they are still a leader.  Senior leadership executives such as directors and VPs should really take a look at the individuals they have in they're management and supervisor team. Many of them do not embody what Baptist portrays themselves to be.
Barely any growth for non-clinical staff, you have individuals who have bachelors and masters degree working in an entry level position such as Patient Representative that could do a better job at being a leader than the current manager. 
I have been in Baptist for over 8 years, I have learned and grown and I am thankful for it; however,  have seen it time and time again that to get promoted in Baptist it is 100% about who you know and are friends with rather than your knowledge and how capable you are to fulfill the position. 
Also, you don't get a promotion like a lot of companies where if you have earned the promotion you just get promoted, you have to apply for a position and then interview for it, all the while there are other people interviewing for the same position.
All about politics! They will interview you even if they know FOR SURE they are giving the position to someone else. I have seen it myself when I've been part of panels for a candidate when another has already been chosen or in mind. Don't waste peoples time!!! 
Pay is definitely not as good as other healthcare systems but they do have great healthcare benefits along with some other incentives. Not sure about other healthcare organizations. And truly not everything should be about money.
Hiring and transferring process is ridiculous! I think it's easier to get into the CIA or the white house. HR needs to get it together and make the process more seamless and communicate better with transferring employees. We should get priority over outside candidates. 
Do not post position that are already going to be filled by someone else that the manager for the department has selected.
If you want to be a leader you cannot speak up to what you think and know is right for the team. You have to agree with leaderships vision even if you know it is wrong. 
Baptist outpatient services is not what it once was and is losing a lot of their good employees.

review_title: Brings new meaning to fight or flight . . .
pros: Beautiful campus, brand new emergency room, clean floors, does promote from within.
cons: Critical Care department antiquated, outmoded, dangerous, lacking in basic supplies.  I have seen a ceiling collapse into the room of a new open heart patient after a light rain storm.

review_title: Great place should be removed from their slogan
job_title: Clinical Business Technology Consultant III in Miami, FL
pros: good benefits not great when compared to other companies.
cons:
1. Not the place to work for sure, it used to be but for some reason they are trying to make people fill out the survey they pass every year "Gallup" to say good things about the company but when the Gallup survey shows low scores they meet with employees to try to force good answers in the survey. Now they even opted to change survey company to try and shift the clearly noticeable decline in employee satisfaction.
2. The recently this year they did away with all the remote days for all IT employees and also did away with the bonus structure and merit increases went from being anywhere from 1 to 6 percent to now just being 1% if you exceed. 
3. Most position are held by the same person for years even in Mgmt even if they don't have the right skill set and treat employees like garbage, also if the Mgmt likes you then you will go places if you hang out with them at happy hour and cater to them. If not you are pretty much in the dog house and can spend years in the same position with minimum salary increat or anything at all. Also promotions are not based on knowledge but rather favoritism and friendships with upper mgmt.
4. They don't like it when people resign the company as if you don't have the right to leave but you have to be careful to make sure that when you leave they don't tag you with HR as DO NO REHIRE or else you can never apply for a job there again. Normally, if someone in mgmt does not like they will tag your HR file just to do the damage even if you didn't do anything wrong. Mgmt does not like any suggestions for improvement specially the CIO wow that lady is lost.
5. When there are team meeting they mgmt always tells you that you are furtunate to have a job and they keep reminding you that everytime as they are doing you a favor for working at BHSF after all you are working and putting in the hours so nobody is doing you a favor. I am sure if you stop or don't deliver your work they will fire so no favor is being done for anyone.
6. All specifically the IT Mgmt are a bunch of people who hang out for happy hour after work and that's how they climb the corporate steps, they cover each other for big mistakes and moeny that is being spent with no reason. The IT mgmt makes so many mistakes when it comes to IT Budgets that I believe if the CEO of the company some days realizes that momey is just being spend senseless someone's head is going to role but since there is a disconnect nobody care and the money goes down the drain, hundreds of thosands of dollars I saw it first hand.
7. As far a talent go, they pride in retaining talent but they don't most talented people leave there a particular AVP in IT that is pretty much lost and she will not take any suggestions from anyone period, this person sticks to old school technology and promises the world but half the time she cannot deliver, the business units know this but the brush it off. BHSF mostly relies on vendors to do the work since there is not talent there to the point that they are still running Window XP at the desktop level when other companies are already running windows 7 or 8 and they pride themselves at being at the cutting edge of technolgy. Even when new hires comes at least for IT they find out soon enought that what was promise is not what it is what they are going to be doing after a year they realize they are losing their skills sets and they decide to leave.

I can go on and on and on but that's BHSF in a nutshell.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, discounts, 403b, ect
cons: opportunity to learn and grow is based "depending on who you know" based on "FAVORITISM" or if you belong to a specific group of people from a specific country or group. The departments run from the tail of the fish to the head of the fish.

pros: New facilities, clean. Usually hire people with values and that are easy to work with. They will work with your schedule if you are in school.
cons: Expect the best of you, in short time, any mistakes will be held against you even when they say it won't.  Work you to death. If you don't have time to eat or go to the bathroom, it's your fault don't expect to be compensated for it more than 2 times.

review_title: Focus is shifting to the “bottom line”...like everyone else out there.
job_title: Multi-modality Imaging Technologist in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: Overall the culture of the company is good,  but things are changing as healthcare in the country changes, and insurances pay less and less, they are definitely cutting expenses where they can, and don’t do as much for employees as they used to.
cons: Unreasonable, or irresponsible patients are usually catered to...responsibility for a patients care is largely placed on the frontline workers, even when the patients don’t play an active role in their own care.

review_title: I've just about had it with this place.
pros: Salary and benefits are the only thing keeping me here.
cons: Middle management is abusive and incompetent. They are unwilling to listen or allow engineers to make technical decisions. Complaints to this effect are met with attempts to institutionalize the problem by putting it into a flow chart and making it a policy. Teams are heavily siloed and turf battles often erupt. Management pursues their pet projects with no regard to what their clients really want/need or what their engineers recommend.

pros: Decent benefits and corporate discounts.
cons: Typical corporate America organization where the rich keep getting richer while the "little people" are taken advantage of, overlooked, and treated HORRIBLY. Will do away with you when it's to their benefit without thinking twice. They try so hard to come across as this fantastic company but when you scratch the surface they're simply downright DISGUSTING. Toss employees aside claiming that they need to cut-back on expenses then turn around and give those salaries to far less-deserving people, all while they WASTE money on absurd things!!!

review_title: Not What it Use to Be
pros: It use to be a great please to work at...family.
cons:
Well HR is definitely not looking out for the best interest on employee. They allow harassment and retaliation from leaders and cover up the indiscretions. Good employees have been lost and there are more to come because of the one sided view the organization has taken giving the power to some leaders to intimidate and harass employees . 
Individuals placed in high positions without any kind of leadership skills,  no experience in the field and without a graduate education just because they know someone. Individuals who harass qualified and educated employees based on personal discriminatory issues or intimidation.
The company culture has changed. People now live in fear of losing jobs, the employees crawling over each other to try to survive and one up the other.  Survival of the fittest! 
The glass ceiling definitely has not been broken. The boys club still exist and those boys really want to make sure they sabotage good female employees. The few women leaders have had to work hard and faced many obstacles to get to where they are today.
Long term employees are no longer valued.

pros: good benefits, opportunity to invest in 401, college fund, retirement package. plenty of activities to participate in, from the corporate run/ walk, the Susan G. Koman fundraiser, fight against autism to the diabetes run. Company advocates to all employees to lead a healthier lifestyle!
cons: Worked for Baptist Health Systems for over eighteen years. Once i reached my limit  as a technician there was no room to grow. Now that the company is going through its financial difficulties, it made it impossible for any chances of a promotion.

pros: Benefits, insurance, bonus, staff acknowledgement by hospital.
cons: Very Unprofessional Staff. Very high school environment. Everyone talked about each other and try to back stab each other.  Supervisors had that mean girl Regina vibe. If you weren’t kissing up to them you weren’t going to move up at all or have peace. It’s pretty disgusting not only that department but other departments too. It’s all about who you know, not what you know. Wouldn’t recommend this place to anyone that is a good , hard, honest worker.

job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in South Miami, FL
pros: Benefits, PTO and much more. It is a great place to work, but watch your back.
cons: lack of training and leadership. If you have friends above, then you will do great. If you don't then watch what you say, time management and smile.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in South Miami, FL
pros: Benefits, tuition reimbursement. Growing company.  Could do more for employee recognition and annual reviews.  Ive been with BHSF 8 years and i will say the first 5 were better than the last 3.
cons: Upper management is out of touch.  Promotions based on who you know.  A lot of knee-jerk decisions and policies.  Very concerned about maintaining their "100 best places to work" image, while promoting a poor performing manager to a director amongst other things.

review_title: Terrible company to work for at DOctors Hospital
job_title: Floor Nurse in Coral Gables, FL
pros: Benefits are good and they reimburse for relocation.
cons: The hospitals within the chain are not all similar. The management team in Nursing Management at  Doctors Hospital is horrid. They do not care about the staff, patients or the work environment. The upper management is so out of tune to safe patient care, or best practices!

pros: great benefits flexible work hours in many departments, good wages on the clinical side of business, Many very caring and committed people.
cons: While benefits are same for non-clinical wages lag and non Hispanic's are often treated poorly and alienated from the large Hispanic/latino population. Additionally workers 50+ are routinely overlooked for promotions regardless of education, skillsets and experience.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Key Largo, FL

Good pay / benefits-- mostly self scheduled 
Family atmosphere/ living in Paradise / staff works well together covering each of our needs when time off comes to play
cons: Took away weekend contract pay / very limited overtime opportunity lately due to tightening up on the budget/ My hospital is one of the smallest in the hospital group -- limited resources/ isolated area in Keys/ expensive area to live .  The only hospital for an hour in either direction

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Miami, FL
pros: I worked at Baptist Health South Florida full-time for over 11 years...it is a great place to work at! Patients and employees are their main objective...in my department they cared about me as an employee,and my family life balance.I enjoyed working for Baptist Health South Florida.
cons: I really do not have cons...It's a big company; nothing is perfect in this life however the organization has always tried their best to be honest with employees about the coming challenges.

pros: Volunteer Opportunities and 401k is available, this is a stable job.
cons: They below market value and reviews of salary and compensation do not come as promised. Insurance is paid for by employee and can cost more than getting insurance elsewhere. Job descriptions are available and made according to job but management cannot and does not have the qualifications to train employees, so employees must "figure it out".

pros: Job security, decent pay, lots of co-workers so the opportunity to meet a bunch of people and make friends is always a plus.
cons: they hire stupid people as managers, people that have no experience in that feild, they try to be different from other baptist hospitals (which makes no sense) so they end up screwing everything up. extremely unorganized.. great benefits if u can afford them which most non-degree workers cant..

pros: The Benefits are what really make the jobs at baptist worth while. Quarterly you can get up to a three hundred dollar bonus. But that depends on customer satisfaction which is usually pretty low

pros: Great benefits and work culture. Worked there for 10 years and have mainly great things to say. The hands on education you receive at all levels is priceless.
cons: It's not the highest pay in south Florida, however, after extensive research, they do offer the best health insurance. Depends on what your situation is, had I worked at another hospital, my bottom line pay would've been significantly less due to high insurance premiums.

pros: I suppose the tuition reimbursement program is okay but once you are given the help you are required to stay working for baptist for 24 months, otherwise you will have to pay it back. Benefits are good too.
cons: LOW PAY GRADE in comparison to other health care competitors. ALWAYS short staffed. POOR yearly merit increases.

a lot of work, must work through breaks to keep up

review_title: Truly a great place to work
